Expectation1: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation1: The client's hair is freshly washed from home and feels clean.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story:
I glanced at the clock as I greeted my next client, Mrs. Lee, who smiled and patted her freshly washed hair. “I just washed it at home, dear. It’s all clean,” she said, settling into my chair. Normally, I’d take her straight to the sink, but her hair really did look and feel spotless. Still, the salon expects every client to have their hair washed and conditioned here before I start cutting. It’s part of our policy, and my manager is strict about it. I could skip the wash, save time, and maybe even make Mrs. Lee happy, but I’d be breaking the rules.

Meanwhile, my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder that my volunteer shift at the community kitchen started in twenty minutes. I was already cutting it close, and if I did the full wash and condition, I’d definitely be late. I knew the kitchen would be fine without me for a bit; there were plenty of volunteers today. But I hated the idea of letting them down or showing up late when I’d promised to be there on time. My hands hovered over the shampoo bottles, my mind torn between the expectations of my job and my commitment to volunteering.
